body:
In contrast to JUnit 4, JUnit 5 has a modular structure. Every module has its own JAR. You can download the individual JARs from [Maven Central](http://search.maven.org/#search%7Cga%7C1%7Cg%3A%22org.junit%22).

In addition, there is a [ZIP distribution](http://search.maven.org/remotecontent?filepath=org/junit/junit-console/5.0.0-ALPHA/junit-console-5.0.0-ALPHA.zip) of junit-console that includes all of its dependencies in the `lib` folder but does not include any engines at the moment. In order to run JUnit 4 tests you'd have to add `junit-4.12.jar` and `junit4-engine.jar` to the classpath, for JUnit 5 you need to add `junit5-api.jar` and `junit5-engine.jar`.

If you use Maven or Gradle you can use the setup we provide in our [sample projects](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5-samples).

Are you looking for a single JAR that includes the contents of all the other JARs? If so, how would you use it? Would a ZIP file containing all of the individual JARs be of any use?

Hassle-free usage in manually managed projects. This goes for writing and compiling test cases and running them:

**junit5-api.jar** is sufficient for writing/compiling.
**junit5-all.jar** would be your choice running your tests on console.

Didn't know about the junit-console ZIP. If it contained the JUnit 5 api+engine by default, i think it was close enough to a "plain-old" JAR distro. 
And on the long run, IDEs (and tools like Ant, etc...) will support version 5 out-of-the-box and hide the required classpath setup anyway.
I've added `junit4-engine`, `junit-4.12`, `junit5-engine`, and `junit5-api` to the ZIP artifact. The next snapshot will already include it.
Do you mind adding the `junit4-runner` JAR as well?

> Do you mind adding the `junit4-runner` JAR as well?

:+1: 

It would also be nice if the script were to add all JARs in `lib` to the class path. This would make it easier to drop in new JARs/versions.

Also: Is this ZIP the recommended way to use the console runner? The user guide is somewhat reticent on [this topic](http://junit.org/junit5/docs/current/user-guide/#running-tests-console-runner).

issue.title: Document how to use ConsoleLauncher archive in the User Guide

milestone.title: 5.0 M4
milestone.description: Themes: test templates, repeated tests, and parameterized tests.

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
I've been trying to get the console runner working for a while now (the one from [the ZIP](http://search.maven.org/remotecontent?filepath=org/junit/junit-console/5.0.0-ALPHA/junit-console-5.0.0-ALPHA.zip) linked in #146) but failed. I'm assuming I'm doing something wrong.

After I failed to launch the script in any sensible configuration, I looked at the code and got it running from within IntelliJ with the following parameters:

```
-p ${my_test_root_directory} -a
```

or

```
-p ${my_test_root_directory} ${name_of_some_test_class}
```

Irritatingly, the same arguments to the script lead to an empty run:

```
junit-console -p ~/code/JUnit-5-Demo/target/test-classes/ -a

Feb 13, 2016 7:46:04 AM org.junit.gen5.launcher.main.ServiceLoaderTestEngineRegistry loadTestEngines
INFO: Discovered TestEngines with IDs []
Test execution started. Number of static tests: 0
Test execution finished.
```

As I said, I'm assuming I'm doing something wrong but I have no idea what it could be.

body: Team discussion result: We will add `junit4-runner` as well but will not change the shell scripts because they are generated by Gradle and we do not want to maintain them ourselves.
`junit4-runner.jar` is now included in the ZIP distribution.

issue.body: https://github.com/johnrengelman/shadow plugin can be used to achieve this goal. This plugjn is capable of merging metadata files (such as META-INF/services) and others. It's also friendly with the `application` plugin; it can produce an executable fat jar when both plugins are applied.

issue.title: Gradle plugin should not use JUnit 4 Engine when runJunit4 is false

milestone.title: 5.0 M1
milestone.description:
First major milestone release for JUnit 5 after the Alpha release

**Epics:**

- Stable, documented IDE-facing APIs (Launcher and Engine API)
- Dynamic tests

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Status Quo

Behind the scenes, the JUnit Gradle plugin uses the `ConsoleRunner` (from the `junit-console` module) to actually execute the test plan. Due to #146, the `junit-console` includes `junit4-engine`, `junit5-engine`, and `junit4-runner` as mandatory run-time dependencies. Consequently, the `junit4` and `junit5` engines are always on the classpath for the JUnit Gradle plugin, which means that those engines are _included_ by default. The `junit4` engine is therefore _included_ even if the `runJunit4` flag for the plugin has been explicitly set to `false`, which is both misleading and unacceptable.
## Related Issues
- #291
- #295
- #303 
- #304 
- #307
## Deliverables
- [x] Add a direct compile-time dependency on `junit-console` in `junit-gradle.gradle`.
- [x] Refer to the `ConsoleRunner` via a class reference within the JUnit Gradle plugin instead of via a hard-coded string.
- [x] Introduce a new `disableStandardTestTask` configuration flag for disabling execution of the standard Gradle `test` task; default the value of the flag to `true`.
- [x] Remove the `runJunit4` configuration flag since it has been superseded by `engines { include ... }` and `engines { exclude ... }` support.
- [x] Covert `version` property plugin configuration into a more appropriately named `platformVersion` property.
- [x] Ensure that only the minimum set of dependencies on JUnit Platform modules is added to the classpath for the task created by the JUnit Gradle plugin.
  - In other words, ensure that undesirable transitive dependencies of the `junit-console` module are no longer added to the classpath.
  - See discussion in [Gradle Forum](https://discuss.gradle.org/t/how-to-add-plugins-dependencies-to-custom-task/18025)
- [x] Ensure that standard project classpaths are no longer modified.

body:
Reopening this issue in order to remove explicit dependencies on JUnit 4 and JUnit 5 from the `ConsoleRunner` and Maven Surefire provider.

For M2, the JUnit Team will come up with a different solution to address the _Plain Old JAR_ and #258.

For Maven users, it would also be convenient to have a couple of BOM POMs available.  I'm not a Gradle user (so I don't know how you're deploying to Maven Central) but if you simply want the extra POMs at the top-level of the project, I'd be happy to contribute them.
